description: Linear algebra: vectors, matrices, systems of linear equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Vector calculus: functions of several variables, vector fields, line and surface integrals, Green's, Stokes' and divergence theorems. Series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software.
name: CALCULUS III

values.comments:
Math 240 is a higher-level Mathematics course that covers a variety of topics including linear algebra, vector calculus, series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations. This course also incorporates the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software. The required text is ‘Advanced Engineering Mathematics’ by Zill Cullen.

Students in this course learned a lot. Overall they found the course to be rewarding and interesting. Exams were difficult but fair. Although Professor Ghrist assigned ample amounts of homework, it proved useful in preparing for the exams.

Students claimed Professor Ghrist was “excellent,” “enthusiastic,” and “humorous.” At least a couple students described him as “the best teacher I have ever had.” Students thoughts that his teaching method was very intuitive, and taught tips and tricks to learn formulas through reasoning, rather that rote memorization. Some felt that Ghrist’s efforts to teach beyond the curriculum was interesting but compromised the amount of time spent learning the core skills tested on exams.

Although the course was challenging and required a significant amount of work, it was still highly recommended for majors and non-majors alike. The pre-requisite is Math 114. Math 240 is a requirement for the Mathematics major.

Math 240 is a higher-level Mathematics course that covers a variety of topics including linear algebra, vector calculus, series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations. This course also incorporates the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software. The required text is ‘Advanced Engineering Mathematics’ by Zill Cullen.

Overall students found the class interesting and understandable. Although students felt the homework was useful in the long run in preparing for exams, many felt it was excessive, “overwhelming” and even “outrageous” compared to other sections. As one student put it, “Plug and chug. No theory involved.” However, many students felt they learned tremendously from this course, and that their efforts paid off in the end. One student commented, “While the course was incredibly hard, I learned a great deal and feel that I really understand the material.”

Professor Donagi was praised as enthusiastic and passionate, overall “an excellent professor.” Students described him as “friendly” and “very helpful.” Of the students taking the common Math 240 exam, many of his students felt that they were better prepared than fellow students in other sections with different professors, even if it meant significantly more homework in addition to weekly quizzes.

Although the course was challenging and required a significant amount of work, it was still highly recommended for majors and non-majors alike. The pre-requisite is Math 114. Math 240 is a requirement for the Mathematics major.

Math 240 is a higher-level Mathematics course that covers a variety of topics including linear algebra, vector calculus, series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations. This course also incorporates the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software. The required text is ‘Advanced Engineering Mathematics’ by Zill Cullen.

Students overall agreed that this was a difficult course. Students felt underprepared for exams compared to other sections and didn’t think the assigned homework nor the recitations were particularly helpful in preparing for common exams.

Professor Kreiger’s lectures tended to be fast-paced and hard to keep up with. One student wrote, “Prof. Krieger is too smart/fast and the pace of his lectures are neck-breaking.” Another student cited poor communication skills as impeding lecture quality, and many felt lectures were “almost pointless” and “worthless.” Others found him “unapproachable and unhelpful” during office hours. One student evidenced poor teaching quality by the fact that this section’s average on the common exam was 20 points lower than that of all sections combined. Although there were many complaints about Kreiger, one student said the quality of the TAs made it even worse. One student, however, praised Kreiger’s insightfulness, describing him as an “outstanding teacher” who deeply cares for his students’ performance.

This course was very challenging. The pre-requisite is Math 114. Math 240 is a requirement for the Mathematics major.
